2002700349.jpg	Kita-Amerika kyōwa seiji-shū jōkan shinzō no utsushi			1854	Japanese print shows an American military officer (probably Captain Henry Adams).	- Title from item. - Annotation in pencil on mount: (1) Envoy plenipotentiary Navy Commodore Matthew C. Perry. (2) Actual portrait of an officer, Republic of North America. (3) Done at the time of the reception at Yokohama. (4) An American officer of Perry's Expedition (not Perry) ca. 1854 by an anonymous artist. Unquestionably it is Captain Adams. Information furnished by Commander Davis. - Annotations, stamps, etc. on verso of print: 1; LC 2585; 47623a (white label). - Gift; Mrs. E. Crane Chadbourne; 1930; (DLC/PP-1930:47623a). - Forms part of: Chadbourne collection of Japanese prints (Library of Congress). - Military officers--American--1850-1860 Portrait prints--Japanese--1850-1860. Woodcuts--Japanese--1850-1860. Portrait prints--Japanese--1850-1860 Woodcuts--Japanese--1850-1860 1 print on hōsho paper : woodcut, b&w ; 28.5 x 21 cm. (block), 31.8 x 23.4 cm. 2002700239.jpg	Gokakoku ... gankirō ni oite sakamori no zu	Ochiai, Yoshiiku, 1833-1904, artist	Japan Yokohama	1860	Japanese triptych print shows visitors from several nations enjoying a party in the Fan Room of the Gankirō.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Japan and the West, Artistic Cross-Fertilization section: A Drinking Party. This triptych depicts foreigners drinking at the Gankirô Tea House, a famous pleasure-seeking place for foreign merchants in Yokohama. People from the five treaty nations England, France, Russia, Holland, and the United States were popular subject matter for Yokohama artists. The five countries were often expanded to six to include China (here refered to as Nanking), a longtime trade partner with Japan. The artist of this print, Ochiai Yoshiiku (1833-1904), was the son of a tea house proprietor in Asakusa. - Title from item. - Signature: Ikkeisai Yoshiiku ga. - Engraving attributed to: Hori Take. - Seal date: Monkey 12. - Triptych in 3 sections (matted together): right (101a), center (101b), left (101c). - Annotations, stamps, etc. on verso of print: 75; 47623a (white label). - Yokohama : prints from nineteenth-century Japan / Ann Yonemura. Washington, D.C. : Arthur M. Sackler Gallery : Smithsonian Institution Press, c1990, no. 59 (p. 149) - The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substance / essays by Sandy Kita ... [et al.]. New York: Harry N. Abrams, in association with the Library of Congress, 2001, no. 106, p. 171 - Earlier control number: 9942.1-7. - Gift; Mrs. E. Crane Chadbourne; 1930; (DLC/PP-1930:47623a). - Forms part of: Chadbourne collection of Japanese prints (Library of Congress). - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - Exhibited: "Steeped in History : The Art of Tea" at the Fowler Museum, University of California, Los Angeles, 2009. - Foreign visitors--Japan--Yokohama-shi--1860 - Entertainment--Japan--Yokohama-shi--1860 - Courtesans--Japan--Yokohama-shi--1860 - Eating & drinking--Japan--Yokohama-shi--1860 - Teahouses--Japan--Yokohama-shi--1860-1870 Triptychs--Japanese--1860. Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1860. Triptychs--Japanese--1860 Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1860 1 print on hōsho paper (3 sheets) : woodcut, color ; 36.5 x 24.5 cm. (each block), 37 x 24.8 cm. (each sheet)	https://www.loc.gov/item/2002700239/	https://tile.loc.gov/storage-services/service/pnp/cph/3g00000/3g08000/3g08400/3g08479r.jpg

2002700284.jpg	Yokohama kenbutsu zue	Utagawa, Yoshikazu, active 1848-1863, artist	Japan Yokohama	1860	Japanese print shows a foreign visitor standing outside a building in Yokohama, Japan. He is looking up and appears to be thinking, his thoughts depicted on the right, outside the space occupied by him, as a framed bust portrait of a woman, possibly his wife, and a clock, possibly a reference to the time that they have been apart.	- Title from item. - Signature: Issen Yoshikazu ga. - Seal date: Monkey 11. - From series entitled: Yokohama kenbutsu zue (Sights in Yokohama). - Annotations, stamps, etc. on verso of print: 47623a (white label); 85-; LC2585. - Inscriptions: Shashinkyō (Photographic mirror), Tokei shashin amerika (Picture of an American clock). - Earlier control number: 9942.25-6. - Gift; Mrs. E. Crane Chadbourne; 1930; (DLC/PP-1930:47623a). - Forms part of: Chadbourne collection of Japanese prints (Library of Congress). - Images from the Floating World: the Japanese print / Richard Lane. New York : G.P. Putnam's Sons, 1978, p. 348, ill. 728 (entitled Foreign melange). - Foreign visitors--Japan--Yokohama-shi--1860 - Spouses--Japan--Yokohama-shi--1860 - Mental states--1860 - Clocks & watches--1860 - Portrait paintings--1860 Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1860. 2002700151.jpg	Oranda, Amerika, Igirisu	Utagawa, Hiroshige, 1826-1869, artist	Japan	1860	Japanese print shows three men gathered around a table: A Dutch man wearing a tricorn hat and holding a pipe, an English man drinking from a glass, and an American wearing a feather headdress and holding a telescope.	- Caption label from exhibit "Collecting Memories": When Japan's port cities opened to foreign trade, it ended two centuries of relative seclusion under the country's policy of sakoku, or "locked country." Japanese artists published colorful woodcut portraits detailing the unfamiliar customs and dress of North Americans, Western Europeans, and Russians who landed on their soil along with the technology and trade they brought with them. Artists, including Hiroshige Utagawa, recorded a wealth of detail and found a ready market for these popular prints both at home and abroad. This, in turn, increased cultural awareness in both the east and west. Here Commodore Perry is depicted in a stylized portrait produced after his first trip to Japan. - Title from item. - Signature: Motome ni ōzu Hiroshige ga (by request). - Seal date: Monkey 12. - Caption on mount: Hollander, American and Englishman. The Indian feather head-dress marks the American, the Dutchman has a tricorn hat and the Englishman holds a glass of ale? - Annotations, stamps, etc. on verso of print: 11; 47623a (white label); LC2585. - Earlier control number: 4162-11. - Gift; Mrs. E. Crane Chadbourne; 1930; (DLC/PP-1930:47623a). - Forms part of: Chadbourne collection of Japanese prints (Library of Congress). - Exhibited: "Collecting Memories: Treasures from the Library of Congress" at the Library of Congress, Thomas Jefferson Building, NW Curtain, Treasure Gallery, Washington, D.C., June 2024 - December 2025. - Foreign visitors--Dutch--Japan--1860 - Foreign visitors--English--Japan--1860 - Foreign visitors--American--Japan--1860 - Hats Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1860. Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1860 1 print on hōsho paper : woodcut, color ; 35 x 25 cm. (block), 35 x 25 cm. (sheet)	https://www.loc.gov/item/2002700151/	https://tile.loc.gov/storage-services/service/pnp/ppmsca/74500/74590r.jpg
2002700152.jpg	Amerika nigiwai no zu	Utagawa, Hiroshige, 1826-1869, artist		1861	Japanese triptych print showing supposed view of an American town square, with people walking around, although the source for the architecture was an illustration of the Fredericksburg Castle near Copenhagen that appeared in the March 7, 1860, issue of the Illustrated London news.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Japan and the West, Artistic Cross-Fertilization section: Prosperous America. In addition to eyewitness accounts, Yokohama-e (Yokohama pictures) often borrowed imagery from secondary sources, such as wood engravings found in Western journals and newspapers. The source for the architecture seen in this print by Utagawa Hiroshige II (1826-1869) was traced to an illustration of Fredericksburg Castle (near Copenhagen) in the March 7, 1860, issue of the Illustrated London News. - Title from item. - Signature: Hiroshige ga. - Seal date: Cock 9. - Triptych formerly housed in 3 separate sections; rehoused in single mat. - Annotation in pencil on mount: H1. - From series entitled: Images of the western world. - Annotations, stamps, etc., on verso of print: 4; LC2585; 47623a (white label). - The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substance / essays by Sandy Kita ... [et al.]. New York: Harry N. Abrams, in association with the Library of Congress, 2001, no. 70 (p. 132) - Yokohama ukiyoe : Reflection of the cultures of Yokohama in days of the port opening / Tsuneo Tamba. [Japan : 1962] - Earlier control number: 4162. - Gift; Mrs. E. Crane Chadbourne; 1930; (DLC/PP-1930:47623a). - Forms part of: Chadbourne collection of Japanese prints (Library of Congress). - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - Source of name (700): LCNA; there are 2 700s, which one is it? Assigned to Hiroshige II based on information from LC exhibit website. - Americans--Clothing & dress--1860-1870 - City & town life--1860-1870 Triptychs--Japanese--Color--1860-1870. 2002700155.jpg	Gaikokujin sen no uchi: jōkisen	Utagawa, Hiroshige, 1826-1869, artist Utagawa, Hiroshige, 1842?-1894, artist	Japan	1861	Japanese print showing a Japanese man and boy standing on the shore of a harbor in which is docked an American steamship, possibly Commodore Perry's ship.	- Caption label from exhibit "Collecting Memories": When Japan's port cities opened to foreign trade, it ended two centuries of relative seclusion under the country's policy of sakoku, or "locked country." Japanese artists published colorful woodcut portraits detailing the unfamiliar customs and dress of North Americans, Western Europeans, and Russians who landed on their soil along with the technology and trade they brought with them. Artists, including Hiroshige Utagawa, recorded a wealth of detail and found a ready market for these popular prints both at home and abroad. This, in turn, increased cultural awareness in both the east and west. Here Commodore Perry is depicted in a stylized portrait produced after his first trip to Japan. - Title from item. - Print created by either Hiroshige II or Hiroshige III. - Signature: Hiroshige ga. - Seal date: Cock 2. - Annotation in pencil on mount: Commodore Perry in Japan. - Annotations, stamps, etc. on verso of print: 7; 47623a. - Earlier control number: 4162-5. - Gift; Mrs. E. 2002700123.jpg	Kita Amerika jinbutsu: Peruri zō		Japan	1854	Japanese print shows head-and-shoulders portrait of Admiral Perry.	- Caption label from exhibit "Collecting Memories": When Japan's port cities opened to foreign trade, it ended two centuries of relative seclusion under the country's policy of sakoku, or "locked country." Japanese artists published colorful woodcut portraits detailing the unfamiliar customs and dress of North Americans, Western Europeans, and Russians who landed on their soil along with the technology and trade they brought with them. Artists, including Hiroshige Utagawa, recorded a wealth of detail and found a ready market for these popular prints both at home and abroad. This, in turn, increased cultural awareness in both the east and west. Here Commodore Perry is depicted in a stylized portrait produced after his first trip to Japan. - Title from item. - Accompanying sheet with a catalog reproduction of print reads: No. 69. Admiral Perry; Yedo-ye; Illustrated. - Annotations, stamps, etc. on recto of print: Commander Perry, 1854, North American Republican G... going up to Yokohama. By Roko. 1725-1. On verso: 1; 47623a (white label); LC2585; 178. - Gift; Mrs. E. Crane Chadbourne; 1930; (DLC/PP-1930:47623a). - Forms part of: Chadbourne collection of Japanese prints (Library of Congress). - Exhibited: "Collecting Memories: Treasures from the Library of Congress" at the Library of Congress, Thomas Jefferson Building, NW Curtain, Treasure Gallery, Washington, D.C., June 2024 - December 2025. - Notes don't match item. - Perry, Matthew Calbraith,--1794-1858--Journeys--Japan Portrait prints--Japanese--1850-1860. Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1850-1860. Portrait prints--Japanese--1850-1860 Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1850-1860 1 print on hōsho paper : woodcut, color ; 37.2 x 25 cm. (block), 37.4 x 25.4 cm. (sheet)	https://www.loc.gov/item/2002700123/	https://tile.loc.gov/storage-services/service/pnp/ppmsca/74500/74586r.jpg

2005675751.jpg	Tanba kanesaka	Andō, Hiroshige, 1797-1858, artist	Japan Tanba Region	1853	Japanese print shows a steep landscape rising to a natural bridge of rocks at upper right, with small figures on path in foreground. In the former province called Tanba.	- Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - From the series: Rokujū-Yo shū Meisho-Zue : Famous views in the sixty-odd provinces. - Signature: Hiroshige hitsu. - Has a censor's 'aratame' seal, a year-month seal, and a ishibari (stone beam). - Format: Vertical Oban Nishikie. - Forms part of: Visual materials from Donald D. 2004666331.jpg	[Kazusa Kanōzan] / Hiroshige-ga.	Andō, Hiroshige, 1797-1858, artist	Fuji Japan Mount	1858	Japanese print shows a view of Mount Fuji across Yedo Bay seen from Rokusozan, Kazusa, with a rural landscape including a large evergreen tree, cherry blossoms, a torii, people, and a horse in the foreground. (Source: Basil Stewart, A guide to Japanese Prints... Chapter XIII : Thirty-Six views of Fuji, no. 35, attributed to Hiroshige II).	- Caption label from exhibit "Sakura": Distant View of Mount Fuiji. Edo period (1600-1868) woodblock prints of famous places, called meisho-e, often contained seasonal indicators including an array of flowers and trees associated with particular times of year. This example from Hiroshige's iconic 36 Views of Mount Fuji shows the majestic peak from Mount Kanō with Edo Bay between them. Fuji is placed at the center distance while a towering pine tree dominates the scene above a torii gate, blossoming cherry trees, and people ascending a winding mountain path. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06 and Basil Stewart's Guide to Japanese prints, 1979, p. 115. - From the series: Fuji Sanjūrokkei : Thirty-six views of Mount Fuji, no. 35. - Format: Vertical Oban Nishikie. - Forms part of: Visual materials from Donald D. Walker collection. - Exhibited: "Sakura : Cherry Blossom as Living Symbol of Friendship" in the Graphic Arts Gallery, Thomas Jefferson Building, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C., 2012. - Country life--Japan--1850-1860 - Torii--Japan--1850-1860 - Fuji, Mount (Japan)--1850-1860 Landscape prints--Japanese--1850-1860. Ukiyo-e--1850-1860. Woodcuts--Color--Japanese--1850-1860. Ukiyo-e--1850-1860 Landscape prints--Japanese--1850-1860 Woodcuts--Color--Japanese--1850-1860 1 print : woodcut, color ; 36 x 24.6 cm.	https://www.loc.gov/item/2004666331/	https://tile.loc.gov/storage-services/service/pnp/jpd/01300/01325r.jpg
2008660269.jpg	Tamagawa-zutsumi no hana	Andō, Hiroshige, 1797-1858, artist	Japan		Print shows sightseers viewing cherry blossoms along the banks of the Tama River at Edo.	- Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - From the series: Meisho edo hyakkei : 100 famous views of Edo. - Format: vertical Oban Nishikie. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Forms part of: Visual materials from Donald D. 2008660302.jpg	Yamato hasedera	Utagawa, Hiroshige, 1826-1869, artist	Japan	1859	Print shows a bird's-eye view of the Hasedera temple in the Yamato Province.	- Caption label from exhibit "Sakura": Celestial View of the Hasedera Temple. Edo period (1600-1868) woodblock prints of famous places, called meisho-e, often contained seasonal indicators including an array of flowers and trees associated with particular times of year. Seen below clouds and cloud-like profusions of springtime sakura blossoms, this view by Hiroshige II (pupil and adopted son of the celebrated Andō Hiroshige) depicts the Hase-dera or Hase Temple, one of the most renowned pilgrimage sites in Japan mentioned in literary works going back to the Heian Period (794-1185). The temple is dedicated to the Bodhisattva Kannon, often referred to as the "Goddess of Mercy." - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - From the series: Shokoku meisho hyakkei : 100 famous views of Japan. - Format: vertical Oban Nishikie. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Forms part of: Visual materials from Donald D. Walker collection. - Exhibited: "Sakura : Cherry Blossom as Living Symbol of Friendship" in the Graphic Arts Gallery, Thomas Jefferson Building, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C., 2012. - Buddhist temples--Japan--1850-1860 - Wooden buildings--Japan--1850-1860 - Flowers--Japan--1850-1860 Bird's-eye view prints--1850-1860. Ukiyo-e--Japanese--Color--1850-1860. Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1850-1860. Bird's-eye view prints--1850-1860 Ukiyo-e--Japanese--Color--1850-1860 Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1850-1860 1 print : woodcut, color ; 35.7 x 23.8 cm.	https://www.loc.gov/item/2008660302/	https://tile.loc.gov/storage-services/service/pnp/jpd/01300/01361r.jpg

2009631860.jpg	Higurashi no sato jiin no rinsen	Andō, Hiroshige, 1797-1858, artist	Japan Tokyo	1857	Print shows sightseers walking among the blossoming trees in the temple gardens at Nippori.	- Caption label from exhibit "Sakura": Temple Gardens. Hiroshige's view near Ueno Hill features two graceful weeping cherry trees in the foreground. The specific site shown has been identified as Shusō-in, one of three Buddhist temple gardens collectively known as Hanamidera or Flower-viewing Temples as well as Jiin Rinsen or Temple Gardens. This album includes fifty woodblock prints from Hiroshige's spectacular assemblage of famous views of Edo (present day Tokyo). - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - From the series: Meisho edo hyakkei : 100 famous views of Edo. - Format: vertical Oban Nishikie. - Illus. in album: Gajō icchō, p. 4. - Forms part of: Visual materials from Donald D. Walker collection. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Exhibited: "Sakura : Cherry Blossom as Living Symbol of Friendship" in the Graphic Arts Gallery, Thomas Jefferson Building, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C., 2012. - Trees--Japan--Tokyo--1850-1860 - Flowers--Japan--Tokyo--1850-1860 - Gardens--Japan--Tokyo--1850-1860 - Sightseers--Japan--Tokyo--1850-1860 - Temples--Japan--Tokyo--1850-1860 - City & town life--Japan--Tokyo--1850-1860 - Tokyo (Japan)--1850-1860 Ukiyo-e--Japanese--Color--1850-1860. Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1850-1860. 2008680227.jpg	[A young girl holding a doll remembers the revelry during a festival beneath blossoming cherry trees on the banks of a river]		Japan	1850		- "東京十二月之内三月" title written, ”國一" artist named. - Caption label from exhibit "Sakura": Hinamatsuri Springtime Girls' Day Festival. The small landscape depicted celebrates Mukōjima situated on the east bank of the Sumida River. This is still a famous destination for viewing the cherry blossom trees that were first planted there by Shōgun Tokugawa Yoshimune (1684-1751). The fashionable young girl in the foreground is holding what is likely an emperor doll associated with the March 3rd Hinamatsuri or Girls Day festival. Kunikazu was a student of Utagawa Kunimasa and the oldest of three artist brothers. Prints of this type, called kuchi-e or "mouth pictures," were made as frontispiece illustrations for novels and literary journals. They were especially popular during the Meiji era (1868-1912) phenomenon. - Title devised by Library staff. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Exhibited: "Sakura : Cherry Blossom as Living Symbol of Friendship" in the Graphic Arts Gallery, Thomas Jefferson Building, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C., 2012. - Girls--Clothing & dress--Japan--1850-1900 - Dolls--Japan--1850-1900 - Festivals--Japan--1850-1900 - Cherry trees--Japan--1850-1900 - Flowers--Japan--1850-1900 Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1850-1900. Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1850-1900 1 print : woodcut, color ; 23.3 x 32.1 cm (sheet)	https://www.loc.gov/item/2008680227/	https://tile.loc.gov/storage-services/service/pnp/jpd/01500/01564r.jpg

2002700039.jpg	Azumabashi kinryūzan enbō	Andō, Hiroshige, 1797-1858, artist	Fuji Japan Mount	1857	View of the Azuma Bridge, Kinryūzan Temple and the surrounding city, and Mount Fuji, seen from a boat.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Major Genres Landscapes section: Distant View of Kinryûzan Temple at Asakusa. Although both worked fluently in a wide range of styles and subject matter, Katsushika Hokusai (1760-1849) and Utagawa Hiroshige (1797-1858) brought landscape imagery in Ukiyo-e to a pinnacle. This scene by Hiroshige comes from a series of pictures of famous places. Hiroshige captures the viewer's eye by radically cropping the boat and its passenger, and placing them in the extreme foreground. In the distance is the Azuma Bridge, built in 1774, stretching in front of Mount Fuji. To the right stands a five-story pagoda with the golden hall of the Kinryûzan Temple, more commonly known as Sensô-ji or the Asakusa Temple. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - From the series: Meisho edo hyakkei : One hundred famous views of Edo. - Format: Vertical Oban Nishikie. - Forms part of: Visual materials from Donald D. Walker collection. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... 2002700008.jpg	Mukōjima miyamoto musashi	Utagawa, Kuniyoshi, 1798-1861, artist		1852	Print shows a head-and-shoulders portrait of the actor Miyamoto Musashi.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Images & Literary Sources section: Miyamoto Musashi at Mukôjima. In this print by Utagawa Kuniyoshi (1798-1861), famous swordsman Miyamoto Musashi is seen in close-up, against the backdrop of Mukôjima. Such images show how Ukiyo-e masters mixed the illustration of literature, legend, or lore with the depiction of landscape. Out of such mixtures, Ukiyo-e developed traditions of its own. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - From the series: Tōto ryūkō sanjūroku kaiseki : Popular restaurants in the Eastern Capitol. - Signed: Ichiy-sai Kuniyoshi. - Format: Vertical Oban Nishikie. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... 2002700000.jpg	Nakayama tomisaburō	Enkyō, Kabukidō, 1749-1803, artist		1796	Portrait of the actor Nakayama Tomisaburō.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Major Genres Actors section: Rare Actor Print. This print is one of only seven known works, all portraits of actors, by Kabukidô Enkyô (1749-1803), the sole follower of the enigmatic Tôshûsai Sharaku (fl. 1794-1795). Nothing was known of Enkyô until 1926, when it was discovered that he also used the name Nakamura Jûsuke II. Under this name he was known as an author and kabuki actor. It is likely that the subject here is Nakayama Tomisaburô, a male actor who played female roles, as identified by an identical print by Enkyô in the collection of the Art Institute of Chicago. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: vertical Oban Nishikie. - Use electronic surrogate. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... New York ..., 2001, no. 2, p. 10. - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - No NAR. Lane: EnkyOo (1749-1803); Nakamura, KabukidOo, JOusuke. Catalog: Kabukid" Enky" (1749-1803). Nichibunken: Kabukidō Enkyō. - Tomisaburō, Nakayama - Actors--Japanese--1790-1800 Portrait prints--Japanese--1790-1800. Ukiyo-e--1790-1800. Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1790-1800. 2002700028.jpg	Nasu no yoichi naozane to atsumori	Adachi, Ginkō, active 1870-1900, artist	Japan	1885	Top shows Japanese warrior Nasu no Yoichi seated on a horse; he is holding a bow in his left hand and looking back at enemy vessels offshore. Bottom shows old warrior Kumagai Naozane killing the young warrior Taira no Atsumori. From the Heike monogatari.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Images & Literary Sources section: Meiji Version of a Classic Story These Meiji Period (1868-1912) prints by Adachi Ginkô (fl. 1874-1897) are connected to Ukiyo-e in both subject matter and style. They were made in the detailed, colorful manner found in innumerable Ukiyo-e prints of warriors. The images are based on the classic war story The Tale of Heike (Heike monogatari). In the top print, a woman places her fan on a pole affixed to the bow of her boat and challenges her enemies to shoot it. An archer then rides his horse into the waves and hits the fan squarely in the middle. The lower image depicts a later scene from the story in which a tough old warrior pursues and kills a young warrior. So brave was the boy that no one regretted the killing more than the old warrior himself. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - From the series: Dainihonshi ryaku zue : Abbreviated pictures of the history of Japan. - Format: vertical Oban Nishikie. - Two images of horizontal chuban, cut marks evident on sheet. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... New York ..., 2001, no. 27, p. 59. - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - Heike monogatari--Illustrations--1880-1890 - Warriors--Japan--1880-1890 - Campaigns & battles--Japan--1880-1890 - War--Japan--1880-1890 Ukiyo-e--1880-1890. 2002700054.jpg	Sake o nomu samurai		Japan	1870	Preliminary drawing for a woodblock design showing a wounded warrior drinking from a bowl.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Images & Literary Sources section: Wounded Warrior. The Library's collection of Japanese art is rich in original drawings, including this preliminary sketch that may have been intended for a woodblock design. The style is reminiscent of the work of Tsukioka Yoshitoshi (1839-1892), especially in the graphic portrayal of the warrior's wound. Among other styles, Yoshitoshi created a series of prints known as "bloody prints" because of their focus on gore. He also used the same nervous brush stroke to create multiple outlines for his forms. At the base of the image is a separate drawing of a head, carefully shaded in red and black washes. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Attributed to the Tsukioka School. - The first drawing for a woodblock design. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... New York ..., 2001, no. 66, p. 127. - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - Warriors--Japan--1870-1890 - Eating & drinking--Japan--1870-1890 Drawings--Japanese--Color--1870-1890. 2002700045.jpg	Kiyomizu komachi	Kikukawa, Eizan, 1787-1867, artist	Japan	1804	Full-length view of the poet Ono no Komachi (ca. ninth century).	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Major Genres Beauties section: Ninth-Century Poet. This print by Kikugawa Eizan (1787-1867) depicts Ono no Komachi (ca. ninth century), a celebrated poet, famed also for her spectacular beauty and its decline in her old age. The translated inscription on this print reads: Even if we say life is limited, The accumulating years would not matter, If one's appearance did not change. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: vertical Oban Nishikie. - Use electronic surrogate. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... 2002700061.jpg	Oshichi	Utagawa, Kuniteru, 1808-1876, artist	Japan Tokyo	1867	Image of the young maiden, Oshichi, who attempted arson out of love and was burned at the stake in 1683. She became a figure in plays with different story lines. Includes vignette image (koma-e) above her head showing a famous place in Edo known as Ai no Uchi.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Japan and the West, Artistic Cross-Fertilization section: Femme Fatale. Yaoya Oshichi (1666-1683) was the daughter of a greengrocer. When the family house burned down in the great fire of 1682, she and her father took refuge in a temple, where Oshichi fell in love with a young man who was studying there. Father and daughter returned home once their house was rebuilt, but, in order to return to the temple to be with her love, Oshichi set fire to the house again. Her punishment was execution by fire in 1683 when she was seventeen. Oshichi's story was recounted in kabuki drama and puppet theater, where her character is portrayed in a kimono bearing the distinctive starburst-like hemp design associated with her. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - From the series: Edo meisho awase no uchi : Famous sites of Edo. - Format: vertical Oban Nishikie. - Signed Kuniteru hitsu. - Seal of carver Hori Yoshiharu and seal reading Masaduya hanmoto Shiba Shinmei mae (publisher's seal) stamped on print. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... New York ..., 2001, no. 81, p. 144. - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - No NAR; Lane, p. 296. Nichibunken: Utagawa Kuniteru. - Yaoya Oshichi,--1668-1683 - Tokyo (Japan)--1860-1870 Portrait prints--Japanese--1860-1870. Ukiyo-e--1860-1870. Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1860-1870. 2002700006.jpg	Zashiki no yūjo to kamuro	Kitao, Shigemasa, 1739-1820, artist	Japan	1764	Two girls in an interior, one seated reading a scroll, the other standing up looking into an insect cage.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Major Genres Beauties section: Delicate Beauty. This print by Kitao Shigemasa (1739-1820) is in the style of Suzuki Harunobu (1724-1770) and shows the small dainty figures associated with his artwork. Harunobu is credited with developing the method of multicolor printing seen here, known as nishiki-e or brocade prints. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: vertical Chuban Nishikie. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... 2002700007.jpg	Yume no ukihashi	Utagawa, Kunisada, 1786-1864, artist	Japan	1854	Floating bridge of dreams. The poem in the image is a pun on the last chapter of Genji.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Images & Literary Sources section: The Floating Bridge of Dreams Allusions to the Tale of Genji are common in Ukiyo-e images. Written early in the eleventh century by Lady Murasaki Shikibu, the novel chronicles the loves and adventures of Prince Genji. The chapter mark seen on the brazier in this print by Utagawa Kunisada (1786-1865) refers to the story titled "Tokonatsu." The poem above the dreamer's head is from the last chapter titled "Floating Bridge of Dreams." The translated poem reads: Happily, I have tethered the Treasure Ship, My dream on the first night of New Year Beneath the floating bridge. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - From the series: Inaka Genji. - Format: vertical Chuban Nishikie. - Signed: Toyokuni ga (painted by Yoyokuni). - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... New York ..., 2001, no. 10, p. 24. - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - Exhibited: Orientation Gallery at the Library of Congress, Washington, D.C., 2025. - Genji monogatari emaki - Dreaming--1850-1860 - Boats--Japan--1850-1860 Ukiyo-e--1850-1860. 2002700018.jpg	Ichikawa monnosuke	Katsukawa, Shunkō, 1743-1812, artist		1772	Full-length depiction of actor Ichikawa Monnosuke with sword in the Thunder God pose.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Early Masters section: Heightened Realism. Katsukawa Shunkô (1743-1812) and his teacher Katsukawa Shunshô (1726-1793) are said to have transformed the caricature-like prints of actors of the early Torii masters into true portraits. This actor, seen in a warrior-like pose reminiscent of the aragoto (rough) style of Edo kabuki actors wears the multiple box (nested rice measures) crest of the Ichikawa family. This print shows the use of printed color in a relatively simple palette, typical of relatively early nishiki-e, or brocade, prints. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: Hosoban Nishikie. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... 2002700095.jpg	Shakuyaku kana ari	Katsushika, Hokusai, 1760-1849, artist	Japan	1833		- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Images & Literary Sources section: Peony and Canary. From the series "Small Flowers" by Katsushika Hokusai (1760-1849), this print is unusual in its background color and in its size. Other examples of this print, found in the British Museum and the Tokyo National Museum, have an intense blue background. This print is similar to one in the James A. Michener Collection in the Honolulu Academy of Arts, and like it, has the combination of censor's and artist's seals. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: vertical Chuban Kishikie. - Later impression, cut down. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - Canaries--Japan--1830-1840 - Peonies--Japan--1830-1840 Ukiyo-e--1830-1840. 2002700027.jpg	Kanbara	Utagawa, Kunisada, 1786-1864, artist	Japan	1836	Woman riding a bull with a village in the background.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Major Genres Beauties section: - Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Major Genres Beauties section: Blending Genres, Beauty in Landscape. Here Utagawa Kunisada (1786-1865) uses Utagawa Hiroshige's famous print of the village of Kanbara from the series The Fifty-three Stages of the Tôkaidô as a backdrop for an enigmatic portrait of a beauty riding a bull. The print reveals the extent to which the artists of Ukiyo-e would borrow images from one another as the traditions of this school developed. Not only did Kunisada use Hiroshige's landscapes in this series, but he also made a second set of half-length portraits of actors paired against these same landscapes. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: vertical Chuban Kishikie. - From the series: Ttōkaidō gojū santsuigi nouchi : The fifty-three stations of the Tōkaidō Road. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... 2002700068.jpg	Shibori kanzashi benichoku	Horai, Hidenobu, active 1805-1825, artist	Japan	1818	Still life arrangement of hair ornaments and toilet articles.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Images & Literary Sources section: Original or Exquisite Copy? Dubious works are occasionally of such high quality that, without direct comparison to a known original, even experts may have difficulty deciding their authenticity. This surimono, which is a picture calendar, illustrates some of the problems of connoisseurship when looking at Ukiyo-e. There are two other known prints comparable to this surimono. The three prints are so similar it is hard to discern any differences among them yet one has been classified by an expert as a copy, made in the early 1890s. Whether or not this print is an original or an exquisite copy has yet to be determined. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: Shikishi Nishikie Surimono. - Modern reproduction. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... New York ..., 2001, no. 90, p. 156. - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - No NAR. Not sure if in Lane (see p. 228). Nichibunken: Hōrai Eishin. - Dressing & grooming equipment--Japan--1810-1830 Still life prints--Japanese--1810-1830. Ukiyo-e--1810-1830. 2002700020.jpg	Karasaki no yau	Katsushika, Hokusai, 1760-1849, artist	Japan Lake Biwa	1804	View of Lake Biwa and the Karasaki pine on a rainy night.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Major Genres Landscapes section: Night Rain on Karasaki Pine. Katsushika Hokusai (1760-1849) was the first Ukiyo-e printmaker to make landscape a primary concern. This example is from his Eight Views of Ômi series, which depicts beautiful scenes of Lake Biwa in Ômi Province in Japan. The subject represents a Japanese transmutation of an old Chinese theme and depicts the Karasaki pine on a rainy night, using a wide and flat space based on the traditional perspective of Chinese-style painting. The Eight Views of Ômi became a popular theme in Ukiyo-e there was even an erotic version of Eight Views of Ômi. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: vertical Chuban Nishikie. - From the series: Shinpan ōmi hakkei : New Editon of Eight Views of Ōmi Province. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... New York ..., 2001, no. 21, p. 44. - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - Preliminary catalog record - Lakes--Japan--1800-1820 - Rain--Japan--1800-1820 - Night--Japan--1800-1820 - Lake Biwa (Japan)--1800-1820 Landscape prints--Japanese--1800-1820. Ukiyo-e--1800-1820. Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1800-1820. 2002700076.jpg	Fuji no yūkei	Utagawa, Kuniyoshi, 1798-1861, artist	Fuji Hakone Japan Machi Mount	1829	The stream of Asazawa in spring with view of Mount Fuji from the hot springs at Hakone.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Major Genres Landscapes section: The Stream of Asazawa. Utagawa Kuniyoshi (1798-1861) produced several privately commissioned prints after 1828, including this view of Mount Fuji from the hot springs at Hakone. The translated poem reads: In the spring wind, there is the scent of the laughing plum. The soft snow melts to be the waters of the Asazawa. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: Shikishiban Nishikie Surimono. - Signed: Ichiy-sai Kuniyoshi ga (Painted by Ichiy-sai Kuniyoshi). - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... 2002700015.jpg	Shōki to yūjo no aiaigasa	Nishimura, Shigenobu, active 1730s-early 1740s, artist	Japan	1726	Shoki, the demon fighter, with his arm around a young woman holding a parasol.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Early Masters section: Shôki with Beauty. This early hand-colored print by Nishimura Shigenobu (fl. 1730s-1740s) is a typical example of parody. Shôki, the fierce demon queller, has his hand around the shoulder of a young woman who has, apparently, tamed him. These prints bear the red collector/dealer seals of Wakai Kanesaburô (1834-1908) and Hayashi Tadamasa (1853-1907), who were among the most prolific dealers of Ukiyo-e. Both seals are seen here in the lower left corner Hayashi's is the small circular seal and Wakai's is oval. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: Hosoban Urushie. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... New York ..., 2001, no. 16, p. 38. - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - No NAR for artist; format follows Lane, p. 324. Nichibunken: Nishimura Shigenobu. - Heroes--Japan--1720-1740 - Courtesans--Japan--1720-1740 Ukiyo-e--1720-1740. Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1720-1740. 2002700017.jpg	Sugawara mitizane zō	Okumura, Masanobu, 1686-1764, artist	Japan	1716	Full-length depiction of Sugawara Michizane (845-903), a nobleman who became the deity Kitano Tenjin.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Early Masters section: Ninth-Century Scholar and Deity. This print by Okumura Masanobu (ca. 1686-1764) depicts a nobleman, Sugawara Michizane (845-903), who, according to Japanese legend, became the god Kitano Tenjin. In a deified form, his spirit is said to have flown to China to learn Zen, paying for his lessons with a sprig of flowering plum. Such portraits of Michizane who became the patron deity of scholarship and learning developed among fourteenth- and fifteenth-century Japanese ink painters and shrines were built throughout Japan in his honor. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Alternate title from exhibit caption. - Format: Hosoban Urushie. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... New York ..., 2001, no. 17, p. 40. - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - Sugawara, Michizane,--845-903 - Nobility--Japan--1710-1740 - Gods--Japanese--1710-1740 Portrait prints--Japanese--1710-1740. 2002700052.jpg	Shirauo	Ryūryūkyo, Shinsai, approximately 1764-1820, artist	Japan	1804	Still life of cut vegetables and a pot containing icefish on a tray.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Images & Literary Sources section: Poetic Cuisine. This is an example of a surimono, literally "printed thing," by Ryûryûkyo Shinsai (ca. 1764-1820). Surimono were privately commissioned prints, made to commemorate special events and given to select individuals as mementos. Surimono usually paired poetic texts with images, and both were typically intended to carry the cachet of "insider knowledge" for a cultured and well-educated audience. The translated poem by Dontontei Wataru (d. 1822) in this surimono reads: Icefish (cooking) like melting snow, Peacefully the wine warms my breast, I feel like a spring of a thousand gold coins. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: Kogata Nishikie Surimono. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... New York ..., 2001, no. 63, p. 124. - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - No NAR. Is in Lane, p. 325; gives 4 other names before R. name. Nichibunken: Ryūryūkyo Shinsai. - Cookery--Japan--1800-1820 Still life prints--Japanese--1800-1820. Ukiyo-e--1800-1820. Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1800-1820. Ukiyo-e--1800-1820 Still life prints--Japanese--1800-1820 Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1800-1820 1 print : woodcut, color ; 10.5 x 13.6 cm.	https://www.loc.gov/item/2002700052/	https://tile.loc.gov/storage-services/service/pnp/jpd/01700/01770r.jpg

2009615185.jpg	Hanami zuki	Torii, Kiyonaga, 1752-1815, artist	Japan	1785	Print shows two women and a child outside a building with cherry trees in blossom.	- Caption label from exhibit "Sakura": Springtime in Edo. Seasonal themes were popular with ukiyo-e (literally "pictures of the floating world") artists of the Edo Period (1600-1868) whose images often reflected the life of the pleasure quarters in Edo, now Tokyo. With her ornamented hairstyle and obi tied in front, the gorgeously-attired woman on the left is recognizable as an oiran or high-ranking courtesan. Close behind her stands a young attendant called a kamuro. The woman on the right, also an apprentice courtesan with her obi tied in front, speaks to the oiran while kneeling and with both hands on the red carpet in a gesture of respect to her senior. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-2006. - From the series: Shin yoshiwara jukkei : Ten views of Shin- Yoshiwara. - Format: vertical Koban Nishikie. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Exhibited: "Sakura : Cherry Blossom as Living Symbol of Friendship" in the Graphic Arts Gallery, Thomas Jefferson Building, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C., 2012. - Cherry trees--Japan--1780-1790 - Women--Social life--Japan--1780-1790 - Courtesans--Japan--1780-1790 - Red-light districts--Japan--1780-1790 Ukiyo-e--Japanese--1780-1790. Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1780-1790. 2002700005.jpg	Sawamura Sōjūrō no Ichihōshi Ōtomo Hitatinosuke Yamatogawa Tomigorō no Sukewaka Yonosuke	Okumura, Toshinobu, active approximately 1717-1750, artist		1716	Sawamura Sojurō and Yamatogawa Tomigoro in the role of a samurai and his page who is offering him a cup of tea.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Early Masters section: Kabuki Actors: Sôjûrô and Tomigorô. This print by Okumura Toshinobu (fl. 1717-1750) depicts two actors Sawamura Sôjûrô I (1685-1756) and Yamatogawa Tomigorô playing the roles of a samurai and his page. Sôjûrô I was the first in a line of nine generations of famed actors bearing the Sôjûrô name. In a technique used by many Ukiyo-e artists, ground metal has been applied to reflect light in selected areas, such as the lamp in the upper left section of the image. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: Hosoban Urushie. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... 2002700002.jpg	Sawamura sōjūrō no soga no jūrō to ichimura takenojō no soga no gorō	Nishimura, Shigenaga, 1697-1756, artist	Japan	1726	Two actors, Sawamura Sojurō I (1689-1756) in a kneeling position and Ichimura Takenojō (standing), dancing with a tsuzumi.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Early Masters section: Kabuki Actors: Sôjûrô and Takenojô. Actors can often be identified in Ukiyo-e prints by the personal crests on their costumes. For example, in this print by Nishimura Shigenaga (1697-1756) the kneeling actor wears an orange blossom crest, identifying him as Ichimura Takenojô. Takenojô was the nephew of a proprietor of a prominent kabuki theater in Edo. He eventually gave up acting and became a Buddhist priest. Above him stands Sawamura Sojurô, identified by the "i" crest. Since actor's crests and names were handed down, they are not always a certain means of identification. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: Hosoban Urushie. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... New York ..., 2001, no. 5, p. 19. - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - Actors--Japanese--1720-1740 - Dance--Japan--1720-1740 - Hand drums--Japanese--1720-1740 Ukiyo-e--1720-1740. Woodcuts--Japanese--Hand-colored--1720-1740. Ukiyo-e--1720-1740 Woodcuts--Japanese--Hand-colored--1720-1740 1 print : woodcut, hand-colored, lacquer, powdered metal ; 31.5 x 14.7 cm.	https://www.loc.gov/item/2002700002/	https://tile.loc.gov/storage-services/service/pnp/jpd/01700/01779r.jpg
2002700053.jpg	Shohei	Torii, Kiyomasu, -1716, artist		1726	Full-length view of the actor Sanjō Kantaro playing a woman's part as a peddler of love letters.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Early Masters section: Stylish Courtesan. This print by Torii Kiyomasu (fl. late 1690s-early 1720s) depicts a woman trampling what are most likely love letters, scattered at her feet. The woman is a courtesan, identified by the fact that her obi sash is tied in front, and probably also by the background willows, which were planted along the banks of the pleasure quarters. The double crests of butterfly and maple leaf on the sleeve of her kimono depict a fad of the late-seventeenth century in which lovers would proclaim their love for one another by overlapping their family crests. Another late-seventeenth-century fad is the long tobacco pipe the woman is holding in her hand, which were smoked by men and women alike. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Title bar caption: Eshi Torii Kiyomasu hitsu; Urogataya hangen. - Format: One of a set of three Hosoban Urushie. - Fūryū kenjin sanpukutsui : A triptych of modern clever people (possibly left panel). - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... New York ..., 2001, no. 65, p. 126. - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - Kantaro, Sanjō--Performances - Actors--Japanese--1720-1740 Portrait prints--Japanese--1720-1740. Ukiyo-e--1720-1740. Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1720-1740. 2002700038.jpg	Yotsuya naitō shinjuku	Andō, Hiroshige, 1797-1858, artist	Japan	1857	View of shops seen beyond horses' legs.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Realia & Reportage section: Playful Perspective. Utagawa Hiroshige (1797-1858) is known for his clever and surprising designs. In this work, the viewer is invited to peer at, below, and beyond the "business end" of a group of horses. The effect seems almost photographic in its suggestion of a real moment and, simultaneously, fantastic in its exaggerated emphasis. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: vertical Oban Nishikie. - From the series: Meisho edo hyakkei : One hundred famous views of Edo. - Second impression Gift; Max Hausman; 1949 Oct. 5. - Forms part of: Visual materials from Donald D. 2002700075.jpg	Horibe yatsubei horibe yajibei shōzō	Utagawa, Kunisada, 1786-1864, artist	Japan	1818	A scene from the drama "The Storehouse of the Loyalties." The two figures in the image are the actors Horibe Yatsubei (Yasubei) and Horibe Yajibe.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Images & Literary Sources section: Father and Son Members of the Forty-Seven Rônin. Depicted in this print by Utagawa Kunisada (1786-1865) are two of the most valiant of the forty-seven rônin, Horibe Yahei and his adopted son, Horibe Yasubei. In a slight acknowledgment to governmental restrictions banning display of certain themes, the warriors are identified in this print by the somewhat fictional names of "Horibe Yajibei" and "Horibe Yatsubei." Clad in black-and-white patterned firefighter's disguises and bearing a pike and a wooden sledgehammer, they appear well prepared, both physically and psychologically, for the final attack on the rival Kô no Moronao (the historical Kira Yoshinaka). - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: vertical Oban Nishikie. - From the series: kanadehon chūshingura youchi ninzū no uchi : Kanadehon Chushingura: among the night raid. - Signed: Motome ni oji Gototei Kunusada ga (painted by Kunisada, on request). - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... 2002700059.jpg	Hangakujo	Taiso, Yoshitoshi, 1839-1892, artist	Japan	1885	Han Gaku, historical woman warrior, armed and armored, seated on a rearing horse.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Images & Literary Sources section: Incomparable Woman Warrior. Yoshitoshi's (1839-1892) dashing woman warrior is based on the historical figure Han Gaku, who lived around the year 1200. She is considered one of the three woman warriors of Japan, along with Empress Jingû and Tomoe Gozen. She lived in the province of Echigo (present-day Niigata) and fought, unsuccessfully, against the Kamakura shogunate. She was sent to Kamakura for execution but was saved by a warrior who asked for her to be spared and then married her. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - From the series: Yoshitoshi mushaburui : A series of warriors by Yoshitoshi. - Format: vertical Oban Nishikie. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... New York ..., 2001, no. 72, p. 135. - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - Warriors--Japan--1880-1890 - Women--Japan--1880-1890 - Horseback riding--Japan--1880-1890 Portrait prints--Japanese--1880-1890. 2002700016.jpg	Ichikawa Ebizō	Torii, Kiyomasu, active 1720-early 1760s, artist		1736	The actor Ichikawa Ebizō, full-length, standing on stage, holding a cannon.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Early Masters section: Referencing a Classic Pose. The actor portrayed here is from the famous Ichikawa line of actors. The plaque in the background of the print bears the name of the well-known Edo temple Sensôji in Asakusa. The print, presumably by Torii Kiyomasu II (fl. 1720s-early 1760s), shows Ichikawa Ebizô on stage, holding a large gun. The actor's stance is reminiscent of that of the "Thunder Gods" seen in Yamato-e a courtly, classical style of painting of the seventeenth-century. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: Hosoban Urushie. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... 2002700022.jpg	Tamanoi	Kosetsu, active 1823-1824, artist	Japan	1820	The Dragon King and two princesses in a scene from the play "The Jewelled Well."	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Images & Literary Sources section: Scene from Medieval Play. This surimono designed by the painter Kôsetsu (fl. 1823-1824) is from a set of fifteen scenes drawn from medieval plays. The play pictured here, "The Jewelled Well," tells the story of the god Hohodemi, who enters the sea to retrieve a fish hook for his brother. Hohodemi meets two princesses and their father, the Dragon King, and stays to live with them in their underwater palace for three years. In the scene shown, the Dragon King returns the fish hook, and the two princesses present jewels on lacquered trays to Hohodemi as he leaves the palace. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: Shikishiban Nishikie Surimono. - From the series: Utai bangumi : A singing performance. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... New York ..., 2001, no. 23, p. 51. - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - Nō--Japan--1820 - Dance--Japan--1820 Ukiyo-e--1820. 2002700009.jpg	Kinokuniya	Utagawa, Toyokuni, 1769-1825, artist		1794	A full-length portrait of the actor Sawamura Sanj-ro III, facing left, holding a fan, in the role of Oboshi Yuranosuke.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Major Genres Actors section: Sawamura Sanjûrô III. This print is from the series Forms of Actors on Stage (Yakusha Butai no Sugata-e) by Utagawa Toyokuni (1769-1825). Each actor in this series is shown full length in a simple, distinctive pose that captures a sense of immediacy. The print on view shows Sawamura Sanjûrô III (1753-1801), a leading actor at the Nakamura theater in Edo, famous for his large, fat ear lobes and his great round eyes. Toyokuni carefully portrayed these features of the actor in this print. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: vertical Oban Nishikie. - From the series: Yakusha butai no sugatae : Portraits of actors. - Sawamura Sojuro III as Ogishi Kurando (excellent condition). - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... 2002700001.jpg	Hizen gotō kujiraryō no zu	Utagawa, Hiroshige, 1826-1869, artist	Japan	1859	Whalers armed with harpoons hunting whales.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Realia & Reportage section: Hunting for Whales. Utagawa Hiroshige II (1826-1869), also known as Ichiyûsai Shigenobu, was the pupil and adopted son of the famous landscape artist, Utagawa Hiroshige. This print portrays whaling, an important Japanese industry since the seventeenth century. At first, whalers used harpoons, as depicted in this print; after 1675, they used specially designed nets. The Japanese whaling industry peaked between 1810 and 1850. By the time Shigenobu designed this print in 1859, whalers from Western nations, hunting in waters off the coast of Japan, had begun to deplete the supply of whales for Japanese fishermen. This print may thus be viewed as a nostalgic vision of a waning industry. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: vertical Oban Nishikie. - From the series: Shokokumreisho hyakkei : One hundred famous views of the country. - Forms part of: Visual materials from Donald D. Walker collection. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... New York ..., 2001, no. 3, p. 14. - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - Whales--Japan--1850-1860 - Whaling--Japan--1850-1860 Marine prints--Japanese--1850-1860. Ukiyo-e--1850-1860. Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1850-1860. Ukiyo-e--1850-1860 Marine prints--Japanese--1850-1860 Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1850-1860 1 print : woodcut, color ; 35.4 x 24.1 cm.	https://www.loc.gov/item/2002700001/	https://tile.loc.gov/storage-services/service/pnp/jpd/01700/01790r.jpg
2002700021.jpg	Haha to ko	Baitei, Kino, 1734-1810, artist	Japan	1750	A woman, holding an infant, and a young boy, both seated.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Images & Literary Sources section: A Maternal Quandary. Ki no Baitei (1734-1810) was a gifted painter in the literati style who shared with his mentor, Yosa no Buson (1716-1884) a taste for haiku poetry and a sense of humor. In this image Baitei displays his sense of irony in everyday life. The poem above the woman holding the infant reads, "Even the kitchen maid whose wife is she whose kid I look after through the winter?" In a household in which the hired help often give birth out of wedlock, the nursemaid in charge wonders who is responsible (presumably the master) for the unexpected increase in the number of children in her care. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Alternate title from exhibit caption for item. - Signed Kyuro. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... New York ..., 2001, no. 22, p. 48. - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - Domestic life--Japan--1750-1810 - Women--Japan--1750-1810 - Children--Japan--1750-1810 - Poetry--Japanese--1750-1810 Ink drawings--Japanese--1750-1810. Ukiyo-e--1750-1810. Ukiyo-e--1750-1810 Ink drawings--Japanese--1750-1810 1 drawing on paper : ink and light colors ; 27.2 x 24.1 cm.	https://www.loc.gov/item/2002700021/	https://tile.loc.gov/storage-services/service/pnp/jpd/01700/01791r.jpg
2002700026.jpg	Miyamoto musashi	Utagawa, Kuniyoshi, 1798-1861, artist	Japan	1847	Man holding up a magnifying glass to look at the famous samurai swordsman Miyamoto Musashi.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Images & Literary Sources section: The Famous Samurai: Miyamoto Musashi In this print by Utagawa Kuniyoshi (1798-1861) a fortuneteller is examining the physiognomy of the famous swordsman Miyamoto Musashi (1584-1645), also known as Niten or "Two Swords" because he mastered a technique of fighting with two swords. Musashi represents the culture of the masterless samurai that developed as warriors lost their masters. The talented Musashi was also a known Ukiyo-e artist. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: vertical Oban Nishikie. - From the series: Eimei sanjūrokukassen : Thirty-six famous battles. - Signed: Ichiy-sai Kuniyoshi. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... New York ..., 2001, no. 25, p. 57. - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - Miyamoto, Musashi,--1584-1645 - Samurai--Japan--1840-1850 Ukiyo-e--1840-1850. 2002700096.jpg	Kinhyōshi yōrin, hero of the Suikoden	Utagawa, Kuniyoshi, 1798-1861, artist	Japan		Kinhyōshi yōrin, hero of the Suikoden.	- Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: Vertical Oban Nishikie. - From the series: Tsūzoku suikoden gōketsu hyakuhachinin no hitori : The popular edition of Suikoden: one of 108 brave warriors. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - Samurai--Japan--1820-1830 Ukiyo-e--1820-1830. 2008660492.jpg	Daiichi no maki	Utagawa, Kunisada, 1786-1864, artist	Japan	1858	Print shows a person, possibly Kiritsubo, holding a lantern in right hand and a blanket over left shoulder.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Images & Literary Sources section: Gingerly Avoiding a Fishy Mess. From 1829 until 1842 Utagawa Kunisada (1786-1864) provided illustrations for Ryûtei Tanehiko's (1783-1842) best-selling seventy-six-volume novel, A Fake Murasaki and a Rustic Genji. Fake Murasaki recounts the early-eleventh-century Japanese classic, The Tale of Genji, but sets the tale in a medieval shogun's mansion and uses the language, customs, and fashions of contemporary , nineteenth-century Edo. In this print, Kunisada revistis a scene from Fake Murasaki in which the shogun's favorite concubine, Hanagiri, has soiled the hem of her kimono with fish intestines which rivals have scattered in her path. Shown here, Hangiri's maid brings a replacement robe and, lamp in hand, gingerly avoids the fishy mess. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - From the series: Genji kōshū yojō : Later series of Genji with instant visual effects. - Format: vertical Oban Nishikie. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Clothing & dress--Japan--1850-1860 Ukiyo-e--Japanese--Color--1850-1860. Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1850-1860. Ukiyo-e--Japanese--Color--1850-1860 Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1850-1860 1 print : woodcut, color ; 35.6 x 25 cm.	https://www.loc.gov/item/2008660492/	https://tile.loc.gov/storage-services/service/pnp/jpd/01700/01795r.jpg
2002700060.jpg	Kanaya uchi ukifune	Isoda, Koryūsai, active 1764-1788, artist	Japan	1772	A woman, full-length, with two attendants sitting or kneeling behind her.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Japan and the West, Artistic Cross-Fertilization section: Fashionable Beauty. The woman in the foreground of this print by Isoda Koryûsai (fl. mid-1760s to 1780s) shares the name of the famous character Ukifune from the Tale of Genji. She glances over her shoulder at two young attendants behind her. Ukiyo-e prints such as this one provided aesthetic influence for Western artists, and it is known that Mary Cassatt (1844-1926) was inspired by Japanese prints. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: vertical Oban Nishikie. - From the series: Hinagata wakana no hatsumoyō : Hiinagata Wakana no Hatsumoyo: New Designs of Young Models. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... New York ..., 2001, no. 80, p. 143. - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - Women--Clothing & dress--Japan--1770-1780 - Women--Domestic life--Japan--1770-1780 Ukiyo-e--1770-1790. Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1770-1790. Ukiyo-e--1770-1790 Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1770-1790 1 print : woodcut, color ; 38 x 25.5 cm.	https://www.loc.gov/item/2002700060/	https://tile.loc.gov/storage-services/service/pnp/jpd/01700/01796r.jpg
2002700019.jpg	Kume no sennin		Japan	1685	Kume Sennin or Kume the Immortal, a recluse with the ability to travel through the air, spying on a young woman washing clothes.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Early Masters section: Kume the Immortal Spies on a Beauty. This sumizuri-e, or monochrome print, is unsigned but the style resembles that of the early master Hishikawa Moronobu (d. 1694) and his school. The young woman doing laundry by the river displays the broad cheeks and long jaw associated with Moronobu, and the print as a whole exhibits the combination of thin and thick wavy calligraphic lines typical of Moronobu. The subject of the print is Kume the Immortal, a renowned recluse who mastered the power to travel through the air at will. The sight of a young woman baring her legs while washing clothes caused Kume to lose his concentration and fall from the sky. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Alternate title from exhibit caption for item. - Format: horizontal Oban Sumizuri-e (monochrome). - Attributed to: Sugimura Jihei. - Probably one sheet of a 12-sheet series. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... New York ..., 2001, no. 20, p. 43. - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - Voyeurism--Japan--1680-1700 - Women--Domestic life--Japan--1680-1700 - Laundry--Japan--1680-1700 Ukiyo-e--1680-1700. Woodcuts--Japanese--1680-1700. Ukiyo-e--1680-1700 Woodcuts--Japanese--1680-1700 1 print : woodcut ; 26.8 x 38.1 cm.	https://www.loc.gov/item/2002700019/	https://tile.loc.gov/storage-services/service/pnp/jpd/01700/01797r.jpg
2002700069.jpg	Byōbu ni e o eg(k?)aku yūjo	Torii, Kiyonobu, 1664-1729, artist	Japan	1704	Woman painting a screen while a reclining man watches and a woman in the background mixes paint or ink.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Early Masters section: Frontispiece to a Set of Erotic Prints. Known from examples in the Art Institute of Chicago, the Hirakawa Museum of Art in Yokohama, and many other collections, this famous print is the frontispiece of a set of twelve erotic prints. This print bears the signature and seal of Torii Kiyonobu I (ca. 1664-1729). Kiyonobu was the founder of the Torii school of artists, a defining force in the development of Ukiyo-e during the first half of the eighteenth century. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: horizontal Oban Sumizurie. - One sheet of a 12-sheet series of erotic prints, cf. Gakken publication "Makura-e". - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... New York ..., 2001, no. 91, p. 157. - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - Painting--Japan--1700-1720 - Women--Japan--1700-1720 - Domestic life--Japan--1700-1720 - Brothels--Japan--1700-1720 Ukiyo-e--1700-1720. Woodcuts--Japanese--1700-1720. Ukiyo-e--1700-1720 Woodcuts--Japanese--1700-1720 1 print : woodcut ; 26 x 36.5 cm.	https://www.loc.gov/item/2002700069/	https://tile.loc.gov/storage-services/service/pnp/jpd/01700/01798r.jpg
2002700030.jpg	Hachidaime ichikawa danjūrō kaja yoshitaka	Utagawa, Kunisada, 1786-1864, artist Takizawa, Bakin, 1767-1848.		1854	Full-length portrait of the actor Ichikawa Danj-ro VIII in a scene from the play Raigō ajari kaisoden.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Major Genres Actors section: The Persistence of Convention. This group of prints by Utagawa Kuniyoshi (1798-1861) and Utagawa Kunisada (1786-1865) illustrates how certain conventions and motifs were sometimes repeated. Each of these works shows a figure with a sword wearing an ankle-length costume fringed with tassels. The figures stand in almost identical poses in both Kuniyoshi's triptych and Kunisada's four-part work. The single sheet, once owned by Oliver Wendell Holmes, shows the figure in the same style of costume, though in a different pose. The Holmes print, which shows Danjûrô VIII, has a label indicating that it is a scene from the play Tale of the Monstrous Rat of the Priest Raigô (Raigô ajari kaisoden), an adaptation of Kyokutei Bakin's (1767-1848) famous 1808 novel of the same title. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: vertical Oban Nishikie. - Probably the top panel from a vertical set of prints. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... New York ..., 2001, no. 28, p. 61. - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - Ichikawa, Danjūrō--Performances - Actors--Japanese--1850-1860 Portrait prints--Japanese--1850-1860. Ukiyo-e--1850-1860. Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1850-1860. Portrait prints--Japanese--1850-1860 Ukiyo-e--1850-1860 Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1850-1860 1 print : woodcut, color ; 36.8 x 24.8 cm.	https://www.loc.gov/item/2002700030/	https://tile.loc.gov/storage-services/service/pnp/jpd/01700/01799r.jpg
2008660493.jpg	Ōya tarō mitsukuni	Taiso, Yoshitoshi, 1839-1892, artist	Japan	1865	Print shows Ōya Tarō Mitsukuni watching a battle scene between armies of skeletons.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Images & Literary Sources section: Yoshitoshi's One Hundred Ghosts. This print is based on the tenth-century story of Princess Taki-yasha, who used witchcraft to avenge the death of her father. Minamoto no Yorinobu, head of the loyalist forces, sent his lieutenant Ôya Tarô Mitsukuni, seen here, to quell any remaining resistance. In the upper right corner of the print the inscription by the famous writer, Kanagaki Robun (1829-1894), reads: The person who sits calmly without losing his wits, looking at the forms of one hundred battling skeletons in the ruined palace at Sôma, is Yorinobu's fearless vassal. The magic, which was intended as a plot to test his strength of will and bring him over to the other side, was the product of Prince Hei's (Taira no Masakado's) daughter, Princess Taki-yasha's, witchcraft. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - From the series: Wakan hyaku monoghatari : 100 Chinese and Japanese tales. - Format: vertical Oban Nishikie. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Samurai--Japan--1860-1870 - Skeletons--1860-1870 - Ghosts--1860-1870 Ukiyo-e--Japanese--Color--1860-1870. Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1860-1870. Ukiyo-e--Japanese--Color--1860-1870 Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1860-1870 1 print : woodcut, color ; 36.5 x 24.2 cm.	https://www.loc.gov/item/2008660493/	https://tile.loc.gov/storage-services/service/pnp/jpd/01800/01800r.jpg

2008660594.jpg	Rōri hakuchō chōjun	Utagawa, Kuniyoshi, 1798-1861, artist	Japan	1826	Print shows a warrior with a sword in his mouth, climbing netting above water, through a hail of arrows.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Images & Literary Sources section: A Hero of the Suikoden. This warrior print by Utagawa Kuniyoshi (1798-1861) depicts Kinhyôshi Yôrin, hero of the Suikoden, a cycle of stories about a notorious gang of twelfth-century Chinese bandits. The hero is shown in a straw cape in the midst of a great storm that has been conjured magically by his enemy, Kôren. The inscription reads, "At the Battle of Kôtôshû, planning to capture the enemy general alive, he hid himself in a grassy place to seek Kôren." - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - From the series: Tsūzoku suikoden gōketsu hyakuhachinin no. hitori : The popular edition of Suikoden: one of 108 brave warriors. - Format: vertical Oban Nishikie. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Warriors--Japan--1820-1830 Ukiyo-e--Japanese--Color--1820-1830. Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1820-1830. Ukiyo-e--Japanese--Color--1820-1830 Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1820-1830 1 print : woodcut, color ; 36.3 x 24.8 cm.	https://www.loc.gov/item/2008660594/	https://tile.loc.gov/storage-services/service/pnp/jpd/01900/01967r.jpg
2008660595.jpg	Ama no iwato		Japan		Print shows a woman, possibly Countess Kami dancing on an overturned washtub with a group of gods facing her and a large fire behind her; in the background a warrior (Tajikara-o(?)) moves the stone gate to the Ama no iwato cave. The purpose of the dance was to lure Amaterasu out of her heavenly cave so that the sun would again shine on the world.	- Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: full color woodblock print. - Probably part of a book of images. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Amaterasu--(Shinto deity) - Dance--Japan--1880-1910 - Gods--Japan--1880-1910 - Warriors--Japan--1880-1910 - Myths--1880-1910 - Sun--1880-1910 Ukiyo-e--Japanese--Color--1880-1910. 2008660831.jpg	Yayoi asukayama hanami	Kitao, Shigemasa, 1739-1820, artist	Japan	1772	Print shows three women and a man having a small tea party beneath blossoming cherry trees.	- Caption label from exhibi "Sakura": Hanami: Blossom Viewing Party. Shigemasa's 18th-century hanami (flower viewing) party scene shows three women and a man at Asukayama Park, opened by Japanese Shōgun Tokugawa Yoshimune (1684-1751) who had its famous cherry trees transplanted there in 1720. Comfortably arranged on a ground cover inside a partial enclosure, they are likely enjoying warmed saké. Such parties continue to be a thriving Japanese pastime, replete with traditional sake and picnic blankets laid out hours in advance at the best sakura viewing spots. Above the image is a haiku poem describing both arboreal and human "blossoms": Murekitaru / Hana mata hana no / Asuka-yama : All flocked together / Blossoms upon blossoms / Asuka Hill - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - From the series: Jūnikagetsu : Twelve months. - Format: vertical Koban Nishikie. - Attributed to: Kitao Shigemasa. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Exhibited: "Sakura : Cherry Blossom as Living Symbol of Friendship" in the Graphic Arts Gallery, Thomas Jefferson Building, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C., 2012. - Women--Clothing & dress--Japan--1770-1780 - Beauty--Japan--1770-1780 - Tea parties--Japan--1770-1780 - Cherry trees--Japan--1770-1780 - Flowers--Japan--1770-1780 Ukiyo-e--Japanese--Color--1770-1780. Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1770-1780--Reproductions--1890-1940. Ukiyo-e--Japanese--Color--1770-1780 Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1770-1780--Reproductions--1890-1940 1 print : woodcut, color ; 21.5 x 15.4 cm.	https://www.loc.gov/item/2008660831/	https://tile.loc.gov/storage-services/service/pnp/jpd/02200/02258r.jpg

2009615203.jpg	Jūdanme	Utagawa, Kuniyasu, 1794-1832, artist	Japan	1815	Print shows a masked man, one of the Rōnin, with a sword attacking Osono, the estranged wife of Gihei, in order to cut her hair to the customary length of a nun making it impossible for her father to marry her off to someone else. While this is taking place Gihei is standing behind a wooden screen. Having passed the test of loyalty to the Rōnin's plan, Gihei is about to be rewarded with his wife's hair and receipt of the divorce letter he wrote in duress.	- Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-2006. - From the series: Chūshingura jūichidan tsuzuki : The eleven acts of Chūshingura. - Format: horizontal Chuban Nishikie. - Actor Mitate. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Forty-seven Rōnin - Theatrical productions--Japan--1790-1810 - Actors--Japan--1810-1820 - Allegiance--Japan--1810-1820 - Spouses--Japan--1810-1820 Ukiyo-e--Japanese--1810-1820. 2009631604.jpg	Kokkei Makoku taiji kaidanji.	Tomisato, Chōmatsu, artist		1904	Print showing a young man representing Japan as the "God of Peace" holding aloft a man, probably Nicholas II, labeled Russia holding a white flag. Japan is standing on a damaged Russian battleship and a man wearing a crown; "Corea" is seen hiding behind the skirt of Japan. Arranged around this central motif are figures representing "Germany", "China", "France", "Tolky" [i.e., Turkey], holding Japanese and Turkish flags and stomping on the Russian flag, "United State [sic], N.
