2002700040.jpg	Hanami no en	Toyohara, Kunichika, 1835-1900, artist	Japan	1862	Ukiyo-e diptych showing richly-dressed man, two children, and two women in a richly-appointed interior.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Realia & Reportage section: Spring Outing in a Villa. This print by Toyohara Kunichika (1835-1900) depicting a lavish outing is possibly an elegant family portrait. The man is shown wearing a jacket with Western-style lapels and a golden dragon design, signed "Rigyoku." The woman in the foreground holds a screen which bears the signature "Sakurai Kiku." The great blue-and-white bowl into which children have placed figures, the man's finely decorated fan, the elegant clothing of the individuals, and the handsome lacquer boxes and cases in the background attest to the wealth of the leisured classes in mid-nineteenth-century Edo. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: Two panels of a vertical Oban Nishikie triptych. - Genji-e. Signatures of Inch-an Rigyoku on the obi (man's garment) and Sakurai Kikujo on the standing screen. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... New York ..., 2001, no. 33, pp. 70-71. - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - Domestic life--Japan--1860-1870 Diptychs--Japanese--1860-1870. Ukiyo-e--1860-1870. Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1860-1870. Ukiyo-e--1860-1870 Diptychs--Japanese--1860-1870 Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1860-1870 1 print (2 sheets) : woodcut, color.	https://www.loc.gov/item/2002700040/	https://tile.loc.gov/storage-services/service/pnp/jpd/02500/02542r.jpg

2002700035.jpg	Kurando Yukinaga Saitō go Kunitake onnagyōja : Osada no tarō Nagamune.	Utagawa, Kuniyoshi, 1798-1861, artist		1847	Four actors (right to left): Kurḡoda Ukinaga, Saitogo Kunitake and Onna Gyōja, and Nagata no Tarō Nagamune.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Major Genres Actors section: The Persistence of Convention. This group of prints by Utagawa Kuniyoshi (1798-1861) and Utagawa Kunisada (1786-1865) illustrates how certain conventions and motifs were sometimes repeated. Each of these works shows a figure with a sword wearing an ankle-length costume fringed with tassels. The figures stand in almost identical poses in both Kuniyoshi's triptych and Kunisada's four-part work. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: vertical Oban Nishikie triptych. - Triptych in 3 sections: left (2214a), center (2214b), right (2214c). - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... 2002700023.jpg	Fūryū genji yuki no nagame	Utagawa, Kunisada, 1786-1864, artist Andō, Hiroshige, 1797-1858, artist	Japan	1853	Ukiyo-e triptych print showing a snowy landscape with a woman brandishing a broom and a man holding an umbrella.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Realia & Reportage section: Material Culture. This triptych is a joint work by Utagawa Kunisada (1786-1865) and Utagawa Hiroshige (1797-1858). The signature "Painted by Toyokuni" (Toyokuni-ga) appears on the left and right prints, while the center piece is signed "Brush of Hiroshige" (Hiroshige hitsu). The careful recording of physical objects, typical of Ukiyo-e, is in abundance here including the elaborate dress of the male figure delicately holding an umbrella above him, and the female figure elegantly brandishing a broom. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Joint work by Utagawa Kunisada and Utagawa Hiroshige. Signature Toyokuni-ga (painted by Toyokuni) is on the left and right panels. Signature Hiroshige hitsu (brush of Hiroshige) is on the center panel. - Format: vertical Oban Nishikie triptych. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... New York ..., 2001, no. 24, p. 54-55. - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - Preliminary catalog record: are these the correct artists? 2002700012.jpg	Kada hone o kezurite kan'u yakizu o ryōji suru zu	Utagawa, Kuniyoshi, 1798-1861, artist	Japan	1853	Ukiyo-e triptych showing the story of Chinese Baron Kan-u playing go while the famous Dr. Kada operates on his arm and the Baron Shujo looks on.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Images & Literary Sources section: The Chinese Baron Kan U. The story of the life of Baron Kan U (Guan Yu) from the famous fourteenth-century novel, Romance of the Three Kingdoms is depicted in this print by Utagawa Kuniyoshi (1798-1861). In this scene the wounded Baron is portrayed as being so stoic that he can play the board game Go while the famous Dr. Ka Da (Hua Da) operates on his arrow-wounded arm. Although obviously fanciful, the story is portrayed in such rich detail as to possess an air of believability. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: vertical Oban Nishikie triptych. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... New York ..., 2001, no. 15, p. 36-37. - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - Nobility--Japan--1850-1860 - Rulers--Japan--1850-1860 - Physicians--Japan--1850-1860 - Surgery--Japan--1850-1860 - Board games--Japan--1850-1860 Triptychs--Japanese--Color--1850-1860. Ukiyo-e--1850-1860. Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1850-1860. Right section: Actress Sadato no Tsuma (Abe no Sadato's wife) with another unidentified actor dressed as an elephant.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Major Genres Actors section: Theatrical Scene. This triptych by Utagawa Kunisadai (1786-1865) depicts a scene from a kabuki play in which six actors appear three are dressed as a tiger, an elephant, and a lion. The figures are identified as Hachiman Tarô Yoshiie (left, with parasol), Abe no Sadatô (center, holding tiger), and Sadatô's wife, Sodehagi, (right, holding long letter). - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: vertical Oban Nishikie triptych, actor print. - Signed: "Motome ni oji Toyokuni" (painted on demand by Toyokuni). - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... 2002700092.jpg	Okamotoya uchi Shigeoka Sugataebiya uchi Sugatano : Tamaya uchi Hanamurasaki.		Japan	1848	Ukiyo-e triptych showing three courtesans (shin yoshiwara). Left section: Hanamurasak from Tamaya house on Edo Street. Center section: Sugatano from Ebiya house on Kyo Street. Right section: Shigeoka from Okamotoya house on Kyo Street.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Major Genres Beauties section: Beauties of the Yoshiwara. These high-ranking courtesans from Edo's famous pleasure district, Yoshiwara, are identified on each print by their names, the houses in which they worked, and the locations of the houses. Gorgeously attired from their elaborately coiffed hair to their lofty platform shoes, these women create a dramatic impression. There were several parallels between kabuki actors and high-ranking courtesans during the Edo Period, including the use of hereditary names that could carry the caché of celebrity down through generations. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: Three panels from a set of vertical Oban Nishikie. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - Courtesans--Japan--1840-1860 Triptychs--Japanese--Color--1840-1860. Ukiyo-e--1840-1860. Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1840-1860. Ukiyo-e--1840-1860 Triptychs--Japanese--Color--1840-1860 Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1840-1860 1 print (3 sheets) : woodcut, color ; 37.8 x 74.8 cm (whole image), 37.8 x 25.4 cm (left panel), 37.7 x 24.9 cm (center panel), 37.8 x 24.5 cm (right panel)	https://www.loc.gov/item/2002700092/	https://tile.loc.gov/storage-services/service/pnp/jpd/02600/02624r.jpg
2002700042.jpg	Fūki kusa sono no yūran	Utagawa, Kunisada, 1823-1880, artist	Japan	1849	Ukiyo-e triptych showing a wealthy visitor at a villa garden with giant flowers.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Realia & Reportage section: Visit to a Peony Garden. Punctuated by giant peonies in the background, this triptych by Utagawa Kunisada (1786-1865) depicts a highly detailed scene in a flower garden most likely the garden at the Buddhist temple Eitai-ji in the Fukagawa section of Edo. Fukagawa was famous for its "unlicensed" pleasure district (as opposed to Yoshiwara, which was licensed and controlled by the regime). Its teahouses and restaurants attracted pleasure seekers from all over Japan. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: vertical Oban Nishikie triptych. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... New York ..., 2001, no. 34, p. 74-75. - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - Gardens--Japan--1840-1860 Triptychs--Japanese--Color--1840-1860. 2002700004.jpg	Shōki zu	Okumura, Masanobu, 1686-1764, artist	China	1741	Shōki the Chinese conqueror in a walking pose, facing left.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Early Masters section: Shôki: The Chinese Demon Queller. This print by Okumura Masanobu (ca. 1686-1764) portrays Shôki, and is one of a number of versions depicting the famous Chinese queller of demons in a walking pose. The artistic style of this print is reminiscent of early painting techniques, as the block-printed lines vary in thickness like the calligraphic brush strokes of ink painters. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Signed: Hōhetsu Tanchō Okumura Bunkaku Masanobu Baio (Studio Okumura Bintaku Masonobu). - Format: Hashirae Urushie (pillar print). - Mounted with a surrounding paper frame imitating that of a hanging scroll. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... New York ..., 2001, no. 7, p. 21. - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - Heroes--China--1740-1760 Portrait prints--Japanese--1740-1760. 2002700046.jpg	Fumi yomu onna to nozoku wakashū	Isoda, Koryūsai, active 1764-1788, artist	Japan	1773	Seated woman reading a scroll as a young man emerges from behind a screen to read over her shoulder.	- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Major Genres Beauties section: Willowy Beauties. These images, possibly by Isoda Koryûsai (fl. mid-1760s to 1780s), were intended for display on support pillars in buildings. In one of the images, a woman is shown engrossed in reading a scroll, perhaps a love letter, while a young man emerges from behind a painted screen and reads over her shoulder. The other print shows two beauties, one holding sumptuous fabric, and the other a long-stemmed pipe that extends beyond the border of the image. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: Hashirae Urushie (pillar print). - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... New York ..., 2001, no. 59, p. 117. - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - Domestic life--Japan--1770-1780 - Reading--Japan--1770-1780 - Love letters--Japan--1770-1780 Ukiyo-e--1770-1780. 2002700031.jpg	Saitō go Kunitake Tada no kurando Yukitsuna : Naruto no mae : Akugenta Yoshihira.	Utagawa, Kunisada, 1823-1880, artist		1847		- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Major Genres Actors section: The Persistence of Convention. This group of prints by Utagawa Kuniyoshi (1798-1861) and Utagawa Kunisada (1786-1865) illustrates how certain conventions and motifs were sometimes repeated. Each of these works shows a figure with a sword wearing an ankle-length costume fringed with tassels. 2002700072.jpg	Meiyo migi ni tekinashi hidarijingorō	Utagawa, Kuniyoshi, 1798-1861, artist	Japan	1847		- Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Realia & Reportage section: An Artist Surrounded by His Creations. The title of this print The Famous, the Unrivalled Hidari Jingorô which appears in the box in the upper right, involves a pun. In Japanese the phrase for "unrivalled" literally means that there is no enemy on the right, which plays against the name of the famous left-handed sculptor Hidari (meaning "left") Jingorô. In this triptych, Utagawa Kuniyoshi (1798-1861) may be presenting himself as Jingorô because the sculptor, shown seated in the center panel, has the artist's identifying seals on his robe and cushion. The cat in the scene is also a reference to Kuniyoshi, who was known for drawing cats. In addition, the sculptures surrounding him are thought to bear the faces of well-known Kabuki actors, some of whom Kuniyoshi depicted in his other prints. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Format: vertical Oban Nishikie triptych. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... New York ..., 2001, no. 100, p. 162-163. - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - Sculpture--Japan--1840-1850 Triptychs--Japanese--Color--1840-1850. Ukiyo-e--1840-1850. Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1840-1850. Ukiyo-e--1840-1850 Triptychs--Japanese--Color--1840-1850 Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1840-1850 1 print (3 sheets) : woodcut, color ; 36.6 x 73.4 cm (whole image), 36.2 x 24.4 cm (left panel), 36.2 x 24.5 cm (center panel), 36.6 x 24.5 cm (right panel)	https://www.loc.gov/item/2002700072/	https://tile.loc.gov/storage-services/service/pnp/jpd/02600/02639r.jpg

2002700085.jpg	[Portraits of actors, often playing roles]	Toyohara, Kunichika, 1835-1900, artist Utagawa, Kuniaki, 1835-1888, artist Utagawa, Kunisada, 1786-1864, artist		1860		- "尚万代御ひゐきの種蒔 更名前作三番叟 (なもかへてしょさのみつくに)" Title in the picture, the artist ""豊國. - Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Major Genres Actors section: Portraits of Actors in Various Roles. This scroll-mounted group of twenty actor prints, many of which are diptychs, includes numerous images of the same actors. Pictured most often is Nakamura Shikan IV (1831-1899), who appears first at the far right. He is shown emerging from a background image amid floating chess game pieces emblazoned with such characters as "performance" and "gold." He sticks his tongue out in a gesture associated with a humorous dance performed at felicitous occasions such as the start of the new theatrical season. Also shown is Sawamura Tanosuke III (1845-1878), a leading male actor famed for playing female roles. Other actors pictured include Ôtani Tomoemon V (1833-1873), Ichimura Uzaemon XIII (1844-1903), and Ichikawa Kuzô III (1836-1911) - Title and other information based on entry in exhibition catalog. - Artists include Utagawa Toyokuni (also known as Utagawa Kunisada) (sheets 8-10, 14-16, 20); Toyohara Kunichika (sheets 1, 2, 4, 5, 11-13, 17-19); and Utagawa Kuniaki (sheets 3, 6). Artist for sheet 7 not yet identified. - Nishike-e (brocade) print. Ōban size. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Four sheets (7, 9, 13, and 20) Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... New York ..., 2001, no. 109, pp. 174-75. - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - Shikan, Nakamura,--1831-1899 - Actors--Japanese--1850-1870 Portrait prints--Japanese--1850-1870. Ukiyo-e--1850-1870. Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1850-1870. Portrait prints--Japanese--1850-1870 Ukiyo-e--1850-1870 Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1850-1870 20 prints (mounted on scroll) : woodcut, color.	https://www.loc.gov/item/2002700085/	https://tile.loc.gov/storage-services/service/pnp/cph/3g00000/3g08000/3g08600/3g08669r.jpg

2002700071.jpg	Bunbuku chagama	Katsushika, Hokusai, 1760-1849.	Japan	1830		- No title written. - Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Images & Literary Sources section: The Badger Tea-Kettle. In the rich Japanese tradition, many folktales deal with animals that transform themselves into human and other forms, both to cause mischief and to bring good fortune. In this folktale entitled "The Magical Tea-Kettle" (Bunbuku chagama), a badger visits a temple and changes into a teakettle in order to avoid discovery. The badger later helps the temple's priest. This masterful sketch of the badger partly transformed into a hanging tea-kettle is from the collection of drawings attributed to the Katsushika school. - Title devised by Library staff. - Attributed to a group of drawings, formerly bound, referred to as the "Hokusai School sketchbook." - Many of the drawings have a small tab of similar paper attached at a later date and numbered in pencil. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... New York ..., 2001, no. 99, p. 161. - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - Badgers--Japan--1830-1850 Brush works--Japanese--1830-1850. Ukiyo-e--Japanese--1830-1850. Wash drawings--Japanese--Color--1830-1850. Ukiyo-e--Japanese--1830-1850 Brush works--Japanese--1830-1850 Wash drawings--Japanese--Color--1830-1850 1 drawing on thin handmade paper : ink wash, color ; 26.8 x 18.9 cm (sheet), 30.6 x 22 cm (mount)	https://www.loc.gov/item/2002700071/	https://tile.loc.gov/storage-services/service/pnp/jpd/02800/02819r.jpg
2009631945.jpg	[Hotei, the god of good fortune, one of the seven lucky gods, right profile, arms folded behind his back, standing in front of his large bottomless bag of goods]	Katsushika, Hokusai, 1760-1849.		1830		- No title written. - Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Images & Literary Sources section: Deity of Good Fortune. Shown here is Hotei, based on an actual Zen monk in China. Recognizable by his rotund proportions and by a large cloth bag (ho-tei), Hotei is believed to bring wealth and comfort to those who worship him. Using a wet brush and ink watered down to provide shades of grey, the artist provides a masterful image which conveys both humor and charm. The image is one of a collection of more than sixty anonymous sketches and drawings attributed to the school of Katsushika Hokusai (1760-1849). - Title devised by Library staff. - Attributed to a group of drawings, formerly bound, referred to as the "Hokusai School sketchbook." - Many of the drawings have a small tab of similar paper attached at a later date and numbered in pencil. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Buddhist gods--Japanese--1830-1850 Brush works--Japanese--1830-1850. Ukiyo-e--Japanese--1830-1850. Wash drawings--Japanese--1830-1850. Ukiyo-e--Japanese--1830-1850 Brush works--Japanese--1830-1850 Wash drawings--Japanese--1830-1850 1 drawing on thin handmade paper : ink wash ; 26.7 x 19.3 cm (sheet), 29.5 x 22.9 cm (mount)	https://www.loc.gov/item/2009631945/	https://tile.loc.gov/storage-services/service/pnp/jpd/02800/02822r.jpg
2002700070.jpg	[Fukurokuju, the god of wisdom, wealth, long life, and happiness, one of the seven lucky gods, standing, facing left]	Katsushika, Hokusai, 1760-1849.		1830		- No title written. - Caption label from exhibit "Floating World," Images & Literary Sources section: Fukurokuju, One of the Seven Deities of Good Fortune. One of the most intriguing series of drawings in the Library's Noyes Collection of Ukiyo-e is a group of sixty images attributed in the bequest documentation to "Anonymous (Katsushika school)" a reference to the school of the renowned Katsushika Hokusai (1760-1849). The images appear to have been previously bound and may actually consist of several distinct sets of drawings. Shown here is, Fukurokuju, deity of longevity, recognized by his robes and cowl, long white beard, and elongated head, which symbolizes wisdom. - Title devised by Library staff. - Attributed to a group of drawings, formerly bound, referred to as the "Hokusai School sketchbook." - Many of the drawings have a small tab of similar paper attached at a later date and numbered in pencil. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Published in: The Floating world of Ukiyo-e ... / essays by Sandy Kita .... New York ..., 2001, no. 98, p. 161. - Exhibited: "The Floating world of Ukiyo-e: shadows, dreams and substances," organized by the Library of Congress, 2001. - Buddhist gods--Japanese--1830-1850 Brush works--Japanese--1830-1850. 2008678322.jpg	Saruwaka-cho Kogiku	Toyohara, Kunichika, 1835-1900, artist	Japan	1878	Ukiyo-e print showing a beautiful woman, Kogiku, looking at photographic portraits (cartes de visite), possibly of her admirers. Photography was so new in Japan when this print was created that the artist is also representing his country's growing contact with the western world and modern technology. The sake and grilled fish in the rectangle above the woman's head show one restaurant's culinary specialties. The long, vertical cartouche on the right calls the woman Kogiku, which translates as "small chrysanthemum," and gives the address in Saruwaka-Cho (now Asakusa), an entertainment district in Japan's capital city. The stamp on the carte de visite represents the noted Tokyo portrait photographer Uchida Kuichi (1844-1875), who had a studio in Asakusa.	- "東計以三十六會席, さるわか町小菊" "國周筆" Written with brush. - Title and other descriptive information devised by Library staff. - From the series: Tokeu sanjuroku kaiseki : Thirty-six restaurants in Tokyo. - Format: Vertical Oban. - Purchase, 2007 (DLC/PP - 2007:104.05) - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Women--Japan--1870-1880 - Restaurants--Japan--1870-1880 - Photographs--Japan--1870-1880 Ukiyo-e--1870. Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1870. Ukiyo-e--1870 Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1870 1 print : woodcut, color ; 37 x 25 cm.	https://www.loc.gov/item/2008678322/	https://tile.loc.gov/storage-services/service/pnp/ppmsca/18800/18843r.jpg

2009615311.jpg	Handaka sonja		Japan		Drawing shows Handaka Sonja, one of the sixteen rakan or arhats disciples of Buddha, sitting next to a flower and holding up a bowl in his left hand. 2009615339.jpg	Ōmu komachi	Katsukawa, Shunshō, 1726-1793, artist	Japan		Fan-shaped print shows a nobleman wearing a long trailing robe, a counsellor for Emperor Yōzei who is sitting on the right in the background, standing in front of the aged poetess Ono Komachi who is sitting outside a small building; the nobleman has delivered a poem from the Emperor to which Komachi responds by changing a single character to alter the meaning. Number 5 in the Nana Komachi series.	- Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-2006. - From the series: Nana komachi : Seven Komachi. - Format: horizontal Koban Nishikie. - From same series as FP 2 - JPD, no. 238. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Ono, Komachi,--active 9th century - Yōzei,--Emperor of Japan,--868-949 - Poets--Japan--1770-1790 - Nobility--Japan--1770-1790 - Emperors--Japan--1770-1790 Ukiyo-e--Japanese--1770-1790. 2009615379.jpg	Nidanme	Katsushika, Hokusai, 1760-1849, artist	Japan		Print shows, in the background, Konami sitting inside a building, probably meeting with her lover Rikiya, who is not visible, though the hilt of a sword can be seen through the opening, at center is Wakasanosuke sitting on a porch, and, in the foreground, Honzō, a samurai and Wakasanosuke's retainer, cutting a pine branch from a small tree in front of the porch, demonstrating his loyalty. Yochibei is being robbed and murdered by Sadakurō. Kampei, out hunting, is seen in the background asking a traveler for a fire to light the wick of his musket. 2009615472.jpg	Sumida tsutsumi hanami no zu	Andō, Hiroshige, 1797-1858, artist	Japan Sumida River	1848	Print shows sightseers walking along pathway viewing cherry blossoms on the bank of the Sumida River.	- Caption label from exhibit "Sakura": Sakura by the Sumida River. Hiroshige's hanami scene along the Sumida River is full of lively action, including a man dancing near a musician strumming the shamisen, a three-stringed banjo-like instrument. To the right another man leans forward to offer saké from a gourd container to a woman who reaches back toward him. Images of the Sumida River, still a famous destination for blossom-viewing in Tokyo, were a recurring theme in Edo Period (1600-1868) prints. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-2006. - From the series: Tōtō meisho : Famous views in the Eastern Capital. - Format: horizontal Oban Nishikie. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Exhibited: "Sakura : Cherry Blossom as Living Symbol of Friendship" in the Graphic Arts Gallery, Thomas Jefferson Building, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C., 2012. - Sightseers--Japan--1840-1860 - Cherry trees--Japan--1840-1860 - Flowers--Japan--1840-1860 - Rivers--Japan--1840-1860 - Sumida River (Japan) Ukiyo-e--Japanese--1840-1860. Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1840-1860. Ukiyo-e--Japanese--1840-1860 Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1840-1860 1 print : woodcut, color ; 24.4 x 37 cm.	https://www.loc.gov/item/2009615472/	https://tile.loc.gov/storage-services/service/pnp/jpd/00500/00501r.jpg

2009615524.jpg	Ouka no nibijin	Torii, Kiyonaga, 1752-1815, artist	Japan	1782	Print shows two women standing beneath a blossoming cherry tree.	- Caption label from exhibit "Sakura": Elegant Beauties. Seasonal themes were popular with ukiyo-e (literally "pictures of the floating world") artists of the Edo Period (1600-1868) whose images often reflected the life of the theater and pleasure districts in the city of Edo, now Tokyo. The tall, slender beauties in Kiyonaga's image echo its elongated format. Such images, called hashira-e or "pillar pictures", were ideal for display on pillars in architectural spaces. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-2006. - Format: Hashirae Nishikie. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Exhibited: "Sakura : Cherry Blossom as Living Symbol of Friendship" in the Graphic Arts Gallery, Thomas Jefferson Building, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C., 2012. - Women--Social life--Japan--1780-1790 - Beauty--Japan--1780-1790 - Flowers--Japan--1780-1790 - Cherry trees--Japan--1780-1790 Pillar prints--1780-1790. Ukiyo-e--Japanese--1780-1790. Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1780-1790. Pillar prints--1780-1790 Ukiyo-e--Japanese--1780-1790 Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1780-1790 1 print : woodcut, color ; 69 x 11.8 cm.	https://www.loc.gov/item/2009615524/	https://tile.loc.gov/storage-services/service/pnp/jpd/00500/00553r.jpg

2009615549.jpg	Yakusha no hanami	Shunkōsai, Hokushū, active approximately 1810-1850, artist	Japan	1818	Print shows four actors looking at a frog near a blossoming cherry tree; the two actors standing next to the tree may be Kataoka Nizaemon VII and, in the onnagata role, Fujikawa Tomokichi II.	- Caption label from exhibit "Sakura": Actors' Hanami Party. This example of a Kamigata print (called Kamigata-e for the region including the cities of Osaka and Kyoto) depicts a group of actors who are distracted from viewing sakura blossoms by a small frog. It was conceived as the second of four sheets in a multi-panel work a full impression of which is in the Boston Museum of Fine Arts collection. The actors shown here have been identified as Fujikawa Tomokichi II (a.k.a. Fujikawa Kayū II), Kataoka Nizaemon VII, Arashi Danpachi I, and Kataoka Korokurō I. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-2006. - Format: second panel of four vertical Oban Nishikie. - Osaka print, possibly by Shioya Chōbē. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Exhibited: "Sakura : Cherry Blossom as Living Symbol of Friendship" in the Graphic Arts Gallery, Thomas Jefferson Building, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C., 2012. - Actors--Japan--1810-1830 - Flowers--Japan--1810-1830 - Cherry trees--Japan--1810-1830 - Frogs--Japan--1810-1830 - Beauty--Japan--1810-1830 Ukiyo-e--Japanese--1810-1830. Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1810-1830. Ukiyo-e--Japanese--1810-1830 Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1810-1830 1 print : woodcut, color ; 37.2 x 24 cm.	https://www.loc.gov/item/2009615549/	https://tile.loc.gov/storage-services/service/pnp/jpd/00500/00579r.jpg

2009615622.jpg	Saga gorō mitsutoki	Utagawa, Kuniyoshi, 1798-1861, artist	Japan	1844	Print shows Mitsutoki wearing protective padded armor from which several arrows are protruding, prostrating himself onboard a Taira ship. He is reporting to "Tomomori", "Emperor Antoku", and others during the battle of Dannoura.	- Caption label from exhibit Art in Action Long Tradition: War Stories. Across time and regional boundaries, art has been used to alternately vilify and glorify. Utagawa Kuniyoshi was among Japanese artists known for dramatic musha-e or warrior pictures. Here, he depicts samurai Saga Gorō Mitsutoki delivering a report to his emperor during the Battle of Dannoura, though wounded by multiple enemy arrows. - Title and other descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-2006. - Format: left panel of a vertical Oban Nishikie triptych. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Exhibited: "Art in Action : Herblock and Fellow Artists Respond to Their Times" in the Graphic Arts Gallery, Thomas Jefferson Building, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C., January 31 - August 17, 2019. - Warriors--Japan--1180-1190 - Armor--1180-1190 - Naval warfare--Japan--1180-1190 - Dannoura, Battle of, Japan, 1185 - Japan--History--Gempei Wars, 1180-1185--Campaigns & battles Ukiyo-e--Japanese--1840-1850. Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1840-1850. Ukiyo-e--Japanese--1840-1850 Woodcuts--Japanese--Color--1840-1850 1 print : woodcut, color ; 35.3 x 24.3 cm.	https://www.loc.gov/item/2009615622/	https://tile.loc.gov/storage-services/service/pnp/jpd/00600/00672r.jpg

2009630335.jpg	Rokoku no senji kannon	Kobayashi, Kiyochika, 1847-1915, artist		1905	Print shows a Japanese soldier with rifle fixed with bayonet smashing Russian railroads and battleships in front of the one thousand-armed Russian Bodhisattva of mercy holding in its many arms battleships and money bags, which are destroyed by the Japanese soldier as quickly as they are added to the Russian war effort.	- Title and descriptive information compiled by Nichibunken-sponsored Edo print specialists in 2005-06. - Signed on block by artist in lower left, includes chop. - Includes extensive Japanese text. - Format: vertical Oban Nishikie. - From the series: Nihon banzai hyakusen hyakushō : Long live Japan: one hundred victories, one hundred laughs. - Forms part of: Japanese prints and drawings (Library of Congress). - Russo-Japanese War, 1904-1905 - Soldiers--Japanese--1900-1910 - War damage--1900-1910 - Buddhist gods--1900-1910 Satires (Visual works)--Japanese--1900-1910.
